Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: Multivariable calculus with practical applications.
A new approach of problem solving.
I learned about multivariable calculus

This course is a great introduction to Multivariable Calculus, with the focus on applications rather than proofs. Everything was explained in a methodical and clear way, which made it easier to understand the complex subject matter.
I learned how to solve multivariable calculus.
How to study math processes.
I gained a solid base in application based multivariable calculus that is especially helpful as an engineering major.
A good grasp of multivariable calculus.
I learned multivariable calculus from this course.
Understanding three dimensions in the context of calculus
Applications of multivariable calculus
I learned how to perform calculus in three dimensions, which greatly intrigued me.
Problem-solving
I learned mulitvariable calculus.
I have learnt how to compute integrals and derivatives of functions of multiple variables.
Working in 3 coordinate systems, evaluating multiple integrals, learning applications of topics we learned, connections to physics
I finally understand how to integrate in 3 space.
I learned multivariable calculus.
I believe that this course did a very good job in preparing me with the practical math skills I will need when pursuing my major.
I learned Multivariable calculus
I learned the skills of vector and multivariable calculus
This class taught me how to think and operate in 3-space and gave me comfort and familiarity with vectors and multiple integration.
This course teaches you how to understand coordinates in three dimensions and all of the operations performed on them, as well as applications to engineering problems (eg flux).
Concepts of multivariable calculus with respect to applications in Engineering

I learned the basics of how to visualize and evaluate integral and differential calculus in 3 dimensions. I also learned many of the valuable theorems useful for engineering. The course also included insightful uses to the mathematics we learned in class, and taught us how to use them to find various types of quantities.
I thoroughly learned Multivariable calculus and the material presented.
I learned about some of the core tenets of multivariable calculus and some vector calculus.
I learned calculus in 3 space along with vector calculus. I also was able to understand physical representations of math equations and ideas.
I learned how to apply multivariable calculus concepts to real world examples and applications such as engineering
I learned about calculus in more than just 2 dimensions. I also was able to learn about the practical uses for calculus in an engineers work.
Math.
I appreciated how organized lecture was.

Great lectures, amazing notes, engaging and interesting classes.

Weaknesses: maybe it would be better if the professor wouldn't go through every single step of the example. It often waists time and we either miss a part of the lecture or go overtime.
Moved extremely fast so I feel that information wasnt getting learned by most but rather remembered

The biggest strength of the course was Prof. Bennett. She made everything so clear and really organized the class in a way that was conducive to learning. She posted detailed lecture notes, explained exactly how we should study for tests, and always made herself available to help when needed. 
Sometimes the content itself was not interesting, but Prof. Bennett always made an effort to find an interesting or applicable way to introduce it and teach it. She was a super active teacher and would sometimes bring in props to help introduce a topic. 
Not very many weaknesses of the course! This was the most engaging and well-taught math class I have ever taken.
A strength to this course was the grading scheme set up.

The biggest strengths in this course come from the way in which it was offered and taught.  Specifically, the efforts done by the professor to put lecture notes and resources online, give exams back in a timely manner, and everything else made the course great. its weaknesses only lie in the repetitiveness of the course material and often boring nature of lecture, but this weakness is likely unavoidable in a class for this subject.

The course is very organized in terms of the schedule, assignments, test preparation and help available. The lectures are also very clear, and organized. I think this is an excellent course and I can't think of any improvements.
Lectures were very tedious and explored topics that weren't overly pertinent to assessments.

I think that this course is very well organized and taught. I think it is structured to make it less stressful and more manageable for the students. The problem sets and the tests are doable. Professor Bennett is great and makes class enjoyable. Overall, for a math lecture, I think this course was very good, and in the end did not have any real weaknesses.
It was an excellent course
There was a lot of help available and it clearly followed the books curriculum.
I liked how this course included applied problems and how we had review sheets. However, I feel like more smaller discussion sections would have been nice.
Strengths: its not math 120
I could not see the board fully sometimes. However, a strength of the class is that the professor was very friendly and ready to help students with difficulties all the time.

Strengths: well organized, felt like the class was setup for our success, very good lectures, accessible help. Weaknesses: problem sets when we also have exams was overwhelming, some of the TAs were very unhelpful
Nothing is a weakness!

The strength of this course was definitely Professor Bennett. She was extremely clear in explaining the topics and her lecture notes were amazing. She also takes time out of the classroom to get to know each of her students and their names! I don't think there were any weaknesses.

Strengths: lectures are easy to follow, the tutors are accessible, and I enjoy the book.

Weakness: sometimes it took a long time for pests to be graded; because they were submitted on paper and not electronically, I didn't always have a scanned version for reference. I would have liked clearer grading on psets (minor issues)
One of the best aspects of this class is how the tests are scheduled and graded. It was done in a way so that I am never overwhelmed with pressure but at the same always motivated to study.

This course was clear, well organized, and had a good layout. The only improvements I would make is to bridge the gap between problem sets and exams better. The exams were consistently significantly harder and asked questions in new, confusing ways.
this course was informative, but relatively boring. making the class more concrete would help keep students engaged, and facilitate better learning
The course was very well organized and the material flowed well together.

The lectures were very clear, but a little fast at times. The problem sets represented what we were expected to know and do on exams. However, there were a lot of problem sets (12), and many of them were very long so it would improve the course if the problem sets were weighted more to reflect the amount of time they took in our final grades.
Fantastic professor, well prepared notes, ample time for problem sets, relevant but challenging tests

Wonderful at teaching only what is necessary without mathematical proofs that are often tedious. I enjoyed all of the material we learned and I found it to be very applicable to other courses. I cannot think of any weaknesses for this course.
Very strong teaching and well chosen problem sets. Tests could be a little bit difficult to prepare for.
Good course overall, wouldn't change anything. Prof. Bennett gave us incredible notes.
The teacher and peer tutors were very clear in explaining concepts. Having notes posted on Canvas was also very helpful.

Strength: problems sets which helped to test the knowledge we learned, having course notes posted online after class was helpful to review what we had learned 
Weakness: having more practice exams in order to help prepare more for exams
Great course. I just felt it was hard for me to catch up at times.
I would recommend this to another student because the concepts are really easy to follow especially with a practical emphasis.

Yes definitely, if you are choosing between this class and math 120 then for sure take this class. Because you do not have to explain every single formula over and over. You just have to understand it and utilize it in the right place. Moreover you have a cheat sheet on every exam (all of the are non- cumulative).

This was the most engaging and well-taught math class I have ever taken, taught by one of the best math teachers I have ever had (Prof. Bennett). Multivariable Calculus can be hard to conceptualize, but Prof. Bennett found the most creative ways to explain the concepts, often using physical props. Although the psets were challenging, Prof. Bennett, TAs, and CBPTs were always willing to give guidance. The tests were challenging, but Prof. Bennett explains exactly how to study for them to best succeed. Overall, this was a fantastic class!
Yes. This class is very manageable if you attend the lectures, take good notes, and do the problem sets. Although the exams are difficult, they are doable with sufficient studying.

Yes. You are likely considering this class as a requirement or prerequisite for a major. If you are debating between Math 120 and this class, I would recommend this one unless you really like proofs. The classes cover the same material but this one focuses more on applications. And, Professor Bennett was really great and explained complicated concepts very well. The homeworks were long but were never too complicated, and the exams were fair.

Other students reading this, take this course in favor of Math 120! It is almost rigged in your favor. If this is the same instructor and format, then the following will be true:
Your lowest two PSets will be dropped
The exams you do better on will count 5% more (40% total) then those you do worse on (30% total)
You are allowed a 8.5x11 cheat sheet to exams

Take this if there is any debate in what course to take!
Yes.

I would recommend this course to another student because it is very organized and application based which is especially valuable to those who struggle with proof-based math. Also Professor Bennett teaches the material clearly and offers a variety of resources to help you succeed in the course in the form of tons of office hours, help sessions, small-group tutoring, and practice exams.
I like the format of this class much more than MATH 120. I shopped both, and this course seemed much more conducive to learning, especially for application based math.
Not unless it is a required class.
Yes. If you want/need to take multivariable calculus, definitely take this course.
Yes. It is definitely a better course than 120
Yes. Its helpful if you just want to be able to apply the math.
I would recommend this course to another person. However, I think that it is important for others to know that this is an applied math course.
Yes, unless you plan to take to further into the math department take this class. You will have no regrets.
Yes, the 4 non-cumulative exams relieved me of stress in learning for the course and helped me adequately prepare to take the exam.

I would recommend this course over 120 if you are deciding between the two. This course actually gave us problems that are going to be applicable to later classes or our future careers so it didn't feel like a waste of time at all. My only advice is to know going into the course that it gets substantially harder as the course goes on.
Yes the professor is amazing and one of a kind!
I would highly recommend taking multivariable calculus especially if it is taught by Professor Bennett.

I would recommend this class to anyone considering engineering related classes, or who likes math but doesn't want to understand it primarily from a theoretical lens if not a practical lens. Bennett in particular is a very good professor
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone pursuing a major in any kind of engineering.
Yes, it was a good course and I learned a lot.
It's not a fun class, but its required for many majors, and other more advanced math topics, so yes, i would reccomend
Absolutely. This is a great math course to take for students interested in multivariable calculus or applied math. It is well organized and does not focus too much on proofs.
Yes, I'd recommend it to people who prefer applications to proofs.
Yes, much more practical than MATH 120 from what I've heard speaking with friends

I would absolutely recommend this course to another student. The material was very applicable to other disciplines and the course was structured very well. The lectures were organized very well and the homework related directly to lecture. Also, the lecture notes posted online were very organized and helpful as well.
For sure a better course to take than MATH 120, also a lot less work and stress.
I would recommend this course to any student looking to improve in math and understand 3d mathematics.
Yes, I haven't taken 120, but this course was certainly doable and a very effective way to learn multivariable.

Yes I would because Professor Bennett is a great professor and with her she helps you to understand the material but the course in itself is hard but it is because the information that we learn is tough in general
Yes it's a good course with a great instructor and many resources to help.
